entry.title: Re: Issue with Workflows: Business Object-Link not redire...
entry.content:
SAP Workflow links depends on Business Object Repository definitions to know how to launch the correct transaction. The task WZRE might not be passing a specific BOR WCB_SETTLEMENT_DOC and hence, SAP does not know it should call WZR3.

To overcome from this, try in SWDD where go to the relevant step using the Task 2000616. Ensure the object passed to the task, is bound as a proper settlement document object type. If it is passed as BUS0001, SAP does not know how to handle it. So you need to adjust the binding so that the workflow passes the correct object reference

entry.title: Re: Actions in Behavior Definition For CDS Custom Entity
entry.content: You are using the READ statement to retrieve the line-item data. If the required data is successfully fetched, update the status on the entity as per your requirement and use the MODIFY statement to persist the changes to the database table. Finally, return the data to the frontend in the result.

entry.title: SAP Business Network for Logistics - Dock Appointment Scheduling: Use Derived Appointment Duration
entry.content:
General 

With this new feature shippers can optimize their dock utilization calculating the loading or unloading durations for example in SAP TM and TM in S/4HANA (Transportation Management) and submit the start and end date and time to SAP Business Network for Logistics - Dock Appointment Scheduling (SAP BN4L FC-DAS).

Shippers can calculate the dock appointment time slot durations based on attributes such as weight and volume for example in Transportation Management, ensuring efficient scheduling and resource allocation. This capability is beneficial for optimizing logistics operations by preventing overbooking and enhancing appointment management for carriers.

For example:

For loading one pallet you specify 01:30 min. Transportation Management would calculate a loading duration 10 PAL x 01:30min = 15:00min

In BN4L FC-DAS this information will be used to derive the appointment duration the user shall book, based on the Time Slot Duration setup in the Loading Point settings.

In the first version of the release with 2507, customer have two options to use this feature:

  • Subcontracting of Freight Orders via TransportationOrderRequest from Transportation Management. Pre-requisite: 2620322 - Business Network for Logistics: Integration to SAP TM and TM in S/4HANA 
  • Provider API for Dock Appointment Scheduling (GenericAppointment_In)

Customers might use this feature in combination of the Maximum consecutive Timeslot Duration feature which was release with 2503 and described here: SAP Business Network for Logistics - Dock Appointment Scheduling: Max. consecutive Timeslot Duration 

New Features in Release 2507

With release 2507, BN4L FC-DAS now supports Derived Appointment Duration. 

 

Feature Enablement in BN4L FC-DAS

You activate the Derived Appointment Duration feature via the Manage Entities app in the respective Loading Point:

  • Enable Use Derived Appointment Duration (only possible if Time Slot Booking is enabled)

 

SAP S4/HANA Transportation Management via Freight Order

In Transportation Management, you can setup planning and scheduling capabilities to determine the start and end dates for a set of activities.

For more details please see, for example:

  • SAP Transportation Management (SAP TM) - Planning 
  • SAP Transportation Management (SAP TM) - Planning - Scheduling 

As an example, we want to use certain criteria to calculate the loading duration at the pick-up stop using the Scheduling Settings in Transportation Management.

The loading duration will be calculated based on the Fixed Loading Duration plus the Variable Loading Duration.

As soon the setup of the Scheduling Settings is done, use the Simulate option to simulate the calculation of an existing Freight Order. The simulation will highlight the settings which were used to calculate the loading duration.

Scheduling your Freight Order in Transportation Management using the respective Planning Profile and Scheduling Settings will calculate the Loading Start and End Date/Time.

When submitting the Freight Order via TransportationOrderRequest message to BN4L-FC the related RequestedLoadingDateTimePeriod fields were filled with the required information.

 

Transportation Management via Freight Order - Self-Book Dock Appointments (carrier booking)

The carrier can book the pick-up appointment for the Freight Order via the Self-Book Dock Appointments app in BN4L-FC-DAS and gets the information concerning the derived or calculated appointment duration from the shipper.

When the carrier books the appointment, the booked time slot(s) must match the calculated duration from the shipper. If an exact match is not possible, the carrier must ensure that the booked time is not exceeded by more than one time slot.

In this example the calculated time slot duration = 27 min and a single time slot is setup by the sipper via Loading Point setting to 15 min. 

This means, the carrier must match as close as possible the 27 min:

  • 2 x 15 min = 30 min ‚úîÔ∏è
  • 1 x 15 min = 15 min ‚úñÔ∏è
  • 3 x 15 min = 45 min ‚úñÔ∏è

The carrier must book two consecutive time slots in order to satisfy the slot duration set by the shipper. If the user books too few or too many slots the system will prevent the booking of the dock appointment.

 

Provider API for Dock Appointment Scheduling (carrier booking)

The same functionality can be achieved using the Provider API for Dock Appointment Scheduling (GenericAppointment_In). If the feature is enabled in the Loading Point settings, the system checks for the following fields to derive the dock appointment duration:

  • RequestedStartDateTime
  • RequestedEndDateTime

 

 

 

End DateTime 2025-07-24T18:00:00.000Z minus Start DateTime 2025-07-24T16:00:00.000Z = 02:00 h 
 
Based on this information, the system calculates the requested slot duration.
 

 

Manage Dock Appointments (shipper booking)

The described restriction of appointment booking applies to the carrier only. In the shipper app Manage Dock Appointments, the shipper user can always deviate from the Maximum Duration of Consecutive Time Slots and the Derived Appointment Duration.

 

Slot Booking Scenarios

 

  1. Exact match = 4 x 15 min slot to match the requested 60 min and <= max. consecutive time slot setting 
  2. Exact match not possible, carrier must book one more slot, 4 x 15 min = 60 min to satisfy the minimum requested 50 min

 

In these scenarios, the maximum consecutive time slot duration is always < calculated/derived appointment duration.

  1. calculated/derived appointment duration > maximum consecutive time slot duration -> only a shipper user can book the full requested appointment duration
  2. calculated/derived appointment duration > maximum consecutive time slot duration -> only a shipper user can book the appointment and can also deviate from the derived duration

 

Same scenario concerning slot duration and derived appointment duration, but 1. has the maximum consecutive time slot duration feature enabled and 2. has the feature disabled.

  1. calculated/derived appointment duration > maximum consecutive time slot duration -> only a shipper user can book the full requested appointment duration
  2. calculated/derived appointment duration without specifying the maximum consecutive time slot duration -> carrier and shipper user can book the full requested appointment duration

 

In case there is a setup, in which the maximum consecutive time slot duration is not a multiple of the time slot duration at this Loading Point.

  1. A single slot will always be bookable by the carrier, event the single slot duration > maximum consecutive time slot duration  
  2. In case more than one slots must be booked based on the derived appointment duration, only a shipper user can book the appointment

Further Information

  • Release Schedule and Dates
  • What's New in SAP Business Network Freight Collaboration
  • What's New in the Test Tenants of SAP Business Network Freight Collaboration
  • Shipper Apps and APIs - Dock Appointment Scheduling
  • Carrier Apps and APIs - Self-Book Dock Appointments
  • Shipper APIs (SOAP APIs) - Dock Appointment Scheduling
  • Business Accelerator Hub - SAP Business Network Freight Collaboration (SOAP API)

entry.title: SAP Customer Checkout, cloud edition - Getting Started: Your All-in-One Guide to the Cloud Offering
entry.content:
Hello Everyone,

Released on June 24th, 2025, the SAP Customer Checkout, cloud edition marks a major milestone in our journey. Whether you're new to SAP Customer Checkout, cloud edition or already familiar with the on-premise version, this blog offers a quick yet comprehensive overview of the cloud edition and guides you to deep-dive resources if you're ready to explore further.

üëâDon't forget to register for our upcoming webinar:
üìÖhttps://events.sap.com/sap-customercheckout-cloudedition-webinars/en_us/home.html

Lets gets started with the basics:

SAP Customer Checkout, cloud edition is a completely new offering. It has completely new materials IDs that partners and customer needs to buy, a new subscription based pricing, and if you noticed a new name as well. 
The old product(OK i must not call it old) is called SAP Customer Checkout. While the new offering retains the brand name yet distinguishes it and is called SAP Customer Checkout, cloud edition. We have new names for the components as well, but the components topics i come to later in the blog.
Versioning
Also the versioning was decided in a way that it helps to easily identity yet differetiate between the two.
The on-premise offering used the versioning number 2.0 FP01/2.0 FP02/../2.0 FP21

The cloud edition started with 3.0 2502.
So when you see 2.0 you know it's the on-premise offering and when you see 3.0 then its the cloud offering.
So what is 2502?
25 is the year 2025
02 is the 2nd feature pack of this year. No you did not miss 2501. It(2501) was an internal test version for us to make it customer ready.

Licensing & Product Lifecycle: If you are currently using the on-premise edition of SAP Customer Checkout, please be aware that you are not automatically entitled to the cloud edition. To use SAP Customer Checkout, cloud edition, you will need to purchase it separately. Your SAP Account Executive or implementation partner can support you in finding the best offer for your situation.

üí°Technical Transformation Behind the Scenes: Beyond the new material numbers, subscription-based pricing, and rebranded naming, the cloud edition represents a significant technical transformation.
While many changes may not be immediately visible to end users, our development team has invested substantial effort in evolving the solution from an on-premise architecture to a cloud-like, scalable platform.
üîßFor the technically inclined: The cloud edition and on-premise edition now run on completely separate code lines, and these differences will continue to grow as the cloud version evolves independently.

For the on-premise offering, there is no change. You can continue to sell or buy it if you wish. The end of mainstream maintenance is till 31st December 2028 and there is no change planned in that. After end of mainstream maintenance, standard SAP release and maintenance strategy will be followed like customer specific maintenance etc. Now let's get back to the cloud edition.

Early Adopter Phase for Cloud Edition: SAP Customer Checkout, cloud edition is currently in an Early Adopter phase. This means
Every sale is manually reviewed and approved by the SAP product team
üìÖThis early adoption phase typically lasts 3 to 6 months, after which the product is expected to move into General Availability (GA)‚Äîremoving the need for manual approval.


Its a hybrid offering.
Like in the past there are 2 components with new but familiar names.
SAP Customer Checkout manager, cloud edition and 
SAP Customer Checkout point-of-sale, cloud edition 

SAP Customer Checkout manager, cloud edition is public cloud hosted by SAP. 
SAP Customer Checkout point-of-sale is on-premise integration application which you install in your point of sale terminals or sometimes laptops üôÇ

And this keeps the solution SAP Customer Checkout, cloud edition offline capable like in the past. So if you lose internet connection or are in a no network zone, this is no problem. You can continue to sell like before.

Yes, there is a catch üôÇ The SAP Customer Checkout point-of-sale must connect to SAP Customer Checkout manager, cloud edition at-least once in 7 days. If used without connecting to SAP Customer Checkout manager, cloud edition for ~7 days it warns you and then later does not allow you to create new transactions. Of-course you can access existing transactions and access the configurations to correct any wrong URL or user password or expired certificate. 

Don't worry: If you start your SAP Customer Checkout point-of-sale after 1 month for a demo,  it won't stop working as it more than 7 days. We have taken care of such technicalities and tried our best to make your life smooth. 

How to get the cloud edition?

üõíWhat Happens After You Buy SAP Customer Checkout, Cloud Edition?
The process of purchasing SAP Customer Checkout, cloud edition is similar to other SAP cloud products, so I won‚Äôt go into the details of how to buy it. Instead, let me walk you through what happens after your purchase is complete:

‚úÖStep 1: Access via SAP for Me
Once you've successfully purchased the product, you‚Äôll gain access to SAP for Me.
There, under the ‚ÄúSystems & Provisioning‚Äù section, you‚Äôll find the product listed.
Simply click on ‚ÄúStart Provisioning‚Äù, and your SAP Customer Checkout manager, cloud edition tenant will start getting prepared.

  • The provisioning process may take several minutes to a few hours
  • Once it's ready, you will see the URL to your tenant ‚Äî this is your entry point to SAP Customer Checkout manager, cloud edition

üíæStep 2: Download the POS Component
In parallel, you‚Äôll also receive access to the SAP Support Portal (SMP), from where you can download the SAP Customer Checkout point-of-sale, cloud edition software.

‚ö†Ô∏èImportant Note:
If you have access to both cloud and on-premise versions, make sure you download the correct one:
Look specifically for
‚û°Ô∏èSAP Customer Checkout point-of-sale, cloud edition
The keyword to look for is cloud edition ‚Äî this version is required to connect to your newly provisioned cloud tenant.

If you want a step-by-step explanation of the entire provisioning process ‚Äî from purchase to system readiness ‚Äî I highly recommend this official resource created by our team: üîóDownload the Guide (PDF)
It‚Äôs packed with screenshots and practical tips to get you started quickly and confidently.

 
How to access? How to connect PoS to manager?

User Management & Identity Integration
SAP Customer Checkout manager, cloud edition is always integrated with a SAP Cloud Identity system. This identity integration enables secure and centralized user authentication and authorization.

üÜïFor New Customers
If you're an entirely new SAP customer, a new SAP Cloud Identity system is automatically created and linked to your SAP Customer Checkout manager, cloud edition tenant during provisioning. Your designated IT contact will receive an email with login credentials and access details to this identity system.

üîÅFor Existing SAP Customers
If you already use SAP Cloud Identity with other SAP products, you can simply re-use your existing identity system.
When you click Start Provisioning in SAP for Me, you'll be prompted to select from a list of available SAP Cloud Identity systems to link with your new SAP Customer Checkout manager, cloud edition tenant.

User roles are assigned using ‚Äúgroups‚Äù in SAP Cloud Identity.
üîëExample: A user with the group CCOM_ADMINISTRATOR will have Administrator access in SAP Customer Checkout manager, cloud edition.

üë•Logging in to the PoS
To enable user access for the SAP Customer Checkout point-of-sale:

  • Ensure the user has the ‚ÄúPoS User‚Äù checkbox selected
  • Assign a password
  • Map the user to the right organizational structure
  • Grant the necessary permissions

This is similar to how user management worked in the on-premise version.

üßæ Managing PoS-Only Users
We hear you‚Äîyou may not want to manage all cashier users in the SAP Cloud Identity system. That‚Äôs absolutely fine.
You can create PoS-only users directly in the SAP Customer Checkout manager, cloud edition. These users:

  • Can log in to the point-of-sale application
  • Cannot access the manager interface
    This offers flexibility for large retail environments with high cashier turnover or local user handling needs.

üîßConnecting PoS to Manager (Technical Users)
To connect SAP Customer Checkout point-of-sale to the cloud manager, you'll need to configure technical users‚Äîalso known as client ID/secret or certificate-based authentication in SAP Cloud Identity terminology.

Since this gets quite technical, we recommend referring to the official documentation:
üìòHow to Connect PoS to Manager
üëâDownload PDF

üìòUser Management Guide
üëâDownload PDF

What can i buy? Can I order test and demo system ? 
üõíLicensing Model ‚Äì Understanding the 4 SKUs
In a nutshell, there are four different SKUs you can purchase for SAP Customer Checkout, cloud edition. Here's a breakdown to help you understand how they work together.

Just like the on-premise offering, you continue to purchase objects (PoS devices).
For example, if you have 500 PoS devices, you would purchase:
‚Äú500 √ó SAP Customer Checkout, cloud edition‚Äù This entitles you to one productiv and one test tenant.

Now, suppose your 500 PoS devices are distributed across three countries‚ÄîGermany, France, and Switzerland‚Äîand you'd prefer one tenant per country. In that case, you can purchase:
‚Äú2 √ó SAP Customer Checkout, cloud edition ‚Äì Additional Production Tenant‚Äù
This gives you a total of three productive tenants while still covering 500 PoS devices.

‚û°Ô∏èIt doesn't matter how the devices are distributed across the tenants‚Äîwhether all 500 connect to one tenant or are split between them. As long as your total number of connected PoS devices doesn‚Äôt exceed the purchased amount (500 in this case), you‚Äôre compliant. If you exceed that limit, SAP‚Äôs post-sales team may contact you for clarification.

üìÑDocument Limits Each purchased PoS device comes with an entitlement of 84,000 documents per year.

So, for 500 devices, you‚Äôre entitled to:
500 √ó 84,000 = 42,000,000 documents per year

It doesn‚Äôt matter how the documents are distributed‚Äîfor example, one PoS might generate 100,000 documents, while another only creates 10. What matters is that the total volume stays within your entitlement.

If you anticipate higher volume, you can purchase: ‚ÄúN √ó SAP Customer Checkout, cloud edition ‚Äì Additional Documents‚Äù

üß™ Test & Demo Systems We also offer a ‚ÄúCloud Test and Demo for SAP Customer Checkout, cloud edition‚Äù SKU.
üëâThis is available at a subsidized price and is not meant for productive use.

üìäUsage Tracking: All usage data‚Äîboth device count and document volume‚Äîis sent to SAP Metering. Customers can view their consumption via this system.
üí°Note: Pricing is not included here intentionally. We are working on publishing this information on sap.com soon, where you'll be able to find it transparently.

SAP Customer Checkout, cloud edition
Type : Base Product
Metric : objects (PoS devices)
Limit : 84,000 documents* per year per object (PoS device).
Initial Minimum buy : 5 objects (PoS devices) (1 productive tenant and 1 test tenant)

SAP Customer Checkout, cloud edition, additional production tenant
Type : Add-on
Metric : tenant

SAP Customer Checkout, cloud edition, additional documents
Type : Add-on
Metric : documents*
Limit : 420,000 documents per year.

Cloud test and demo for SAP Customer Checkout, cloud edition
Type : Base Product
Metric : entitlements package
Entitlement : 5 objects and 12,000 documents per year per object.

What's the biggest difference? Is there a 100% feature parity?

I‚Äôd say the biggest difference lies in the technical transformation the product underwent to become truly cloud-ready‚Äîthough much of this change is under the hood and not immediately visible to end users.

So let‚Äôs focus on what is visible. Below are my top 5 notable changes, blending both functional and consumption-based aspects. Of course, your own top 5 might differ based on your business context, but these stand out to me:

1Ô∏è‚É£User Management Has Changed Completely
User management is now fully integrated with SAP Cloud Identity Services. There are three distinct types of users:

  • Identity Service Users: Managed in SAP Cloud Identity and used for accessing the Manager UI
  • PoS Users: Can be created directly in the Manager (for logging in to the PoS only)
  • Technical Users: Used for connecting systems (e.g., PoS ‚Üî Manager) using credentials or certificates
    This setup brings enterprise-grade security and identity federation to the product.

2Ô∏è‚É£New Self-Checkout Interface ‚Äì At No Extra Cost
We‚Äôve introduced a brand-new, modern user interface specifically designed for self-checkout scenarios‚Äîand it‚Äôs included in your subscription at no additional cost üéâ.

3Ô∏è‚É£Mobile Order Not Yet Supported
As of now, mobile order functionality is not available in the cloud edition. While it‚Äôs on our internal roadmap, there are no official commitments. We‚Äôll share updates as the feature progresses.

4Ô∏è‚É£PoS Must Connect to Manager at Least Once Every 7 Days
To maintain offline capability while ensuring cloud integration, the PoS device must connect to the SAP Customer Checkout manager, cloud edition at least once every 7 days. After 7 days of no connection, new transactions cannot be created. Existing data remains accessible, and connection errors can be fixed without data loss.
We‚Äôve built in smart handling to avoid blocking demo setups or first-time use

5Ô∏è‚É£You Buy PoS Devices with Document Entitlement
In the on-premise model, you owned the infrastructure and scaled it as needed.
In the cloud model, SAP manages the infrastructure, and for each PoS device you purchase, you're entitled to:

  • 84,000 documents per year per PoS device
  • Usage is calculated in total, not per device (e.g., one device can use 100K, another only 10)
    All usage is tracked via the SAP Metering Service. This approach enables predictable, scalable pricing and fair consumption-based licensing.

How to migrate customers from on-premise offering to cloud edition?
While we are not offering any magic tools as of now to migrate customers from on-premise offering to cloud edition. However, we fully recognize the importance of this topic for our customers and partners. While all i can say is our legal statement "no commitments.".
We will share more update on this topic once we have some. Stay tuned‚Äîthis space will evolve.

In this blog, you have learnt about SAP Customer Checkout, cloud edition.
Hope you enjoyed the blog. Best of luck with your SAP Customer Checkout, cloud edition journey.

Help: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_CUSTOMER_CHECKOUT_CLOUD

PartnerEdge https://partneredge.sap.com/en/products/sapcc.html
https://partneredge.sap.com/en/products/sapcc/scccld/about.html

Feel free to comment and give feedback about the blog.

About me: 
My name is Bikash Bansal. I work for SAP SE, Germany. My current role is of Product Owner for SAP Customer Checkout, cloud edition. You can find more blogs from me about SAP Customer Checkout here .

entry.title: The Complete Guide to Calling Actions in UI5 with Custom Code
entry.content:
In the past I‚Äôve had to implement actions in SAPUI5 every now and then. Because I mostly work with Fiori elements now, hand-coding actions has become a rare task for me ‚Äî and whenever I do need to do it, the official docs are pretty thin and the code samples are sparse.

With this post (and a CAP sample project) I want to walk you through the process ‚Äî and leave a note to my future self ‚Äî on how to wire up actions in SAPUI5.

What exactly are ‚Äúactions‚Äù and ‚Äúfunctions‚Äù?

Both Actions and Functions are service operations defined in OData / CAP that go beyond the standard CRUD verbs:

Concept

Side effects

Return type

Typical use case

Action

Yes (write)

void / entity / collection

Post an order, approve a request

Function

No (read-only)

scalar / entity / collection

Calculate price, fetch KPIs

In CAP there are two scopes for both actions and functions:

  • Bound ‚Äî tied to a single instance or collection of an entity.

  • Unbound ‚Äî defined at service level, usable anywhere.

Quick Start

git clone https://github.com/your-org/ui5-call-action.git
cd ui5-call-action
npm install          # installs CAP, UI5 tooling, etc.
npm run watch           # starts CAP + FE/Freestyle apps

Open in your browser http://localhost:4004:

  • UI5 V4 Fiori elements ‚Üí /com.marianzeis.books

  • UI5 V2 Fiori elements ‚Üí /com.marianzeis.booksv2

  • UI5 V4 Freestyle ‚Üí /com.freestyle

  • UI5 V2 Freestyle ‚Üí /com.freestyle-v2

 

Implementing actions in CAP

I‚Äôve put together a classic Bookshop example and sprinkled in a handful of actions.
Full repo: github.com/marianfoo/ui5-call-action

Bound actions

Action

What it does

Parameters

promoteBook

Promote a book

‚Äî

setDiscount

Apply a discount

percentage, reason

halfPrice

Cut price in half

‚Äî

addChapter

Add a chapter

title, pages

Unbound actions

Action

What it does

Parameters

refreshCatalog

Refresh catalog

‚Äî

generateReport

Generate report

type, dateFrom, dateTo

createBooksAndChapters

Bulk create books + chapters

books[] and chapters[] (deep parameter)

Functions (read-only)

Function

Scope

Description

getCurrentPrice

bound

Return current book price

getSumBookPrices

unbound

Sum of all book prices

Definitions ‚Üí srv/bookshop-service.cds
Handlers ‚Üí srv/bookshop-service.js

OData V2 quick note

CAP speaks OData V4 out-of-the-box. To expose an OData V2 endpoint, install @cap-js-community/odata-v2-adapter. The service will be reachable at:

http://localhost:4004/odata/v2/bookshop

SAPUI5 via annotations

The smoothest route in UI5 is Fiori elements. Just add an annotation and the button appears. Example for promoteBook. :

{
  $Type: 'UI.DataFieldForAction',
  Label: 'CAP Promote Book',
  Action: 'BookshopService.promoteBook'
}

The actions are now visible in the table header. The buttons with the prefix ‚ÄòCAP‚Äô are defined with the annotation, the buttons with the prefix ‚ÄòCUST‚Äô are custom actions defined and implemented in the frontend.

 

SAPUI5 with custom code

To compare APIs I created two freestyle apps:

App

Tech

Key APIs

/app/freestyle

OData V4, TypeScript

invoke(), execute()

/app/freestyle-v2

OData V2, TypeScript

callFunction()

/app/books, /app/books-v2

Fiori elements

invokeAction() / invokeActions()

OData V4 freestyle app

Controller ‚Üí MainView.controller.ts

// Legacy pattern
const actionBinding = odataModel.bindContext(
  "BookshopService.promoteBook(...)",
  bookContext
);
await actionBinding.execute();

// Modern pattern
await actionBinding.invoke();

 

OData V2 freestyle app

Controller ‚Üí MainView.controller.ts

const data = await new Promise((resolve, reject) => {
  model.callFunction("/Books_promoteBook", {
    method: "POST",
    urlParameters: { ID: bookId, IsActiveEntity: true },
    success: resolve,
    error: reject
  });
});

Paths differ:

  • V4 ‚Üí BookshopService.promoteBook(...)

  • V2 ‚Üí /Books_promoteBook

 

Custom code in Fiori elements (V4 & V2)

Fiori elements already renders ‚ÄúCAP‚Äù buttons for every annotated action, but you can go further and add CUST logic without leaving the Fiori elements shell. All you need is an ext/controller/*.ts|js file and manifest.json metadata that points to it. Inside that controller you work with ExtensionAPI:

  • getEditFlow().invokeAction() ‚Äî V4 helper that wraps OData calls, busy indicators, draft handling, side-effects and messaging.

  • extensionAPI.invokeActions() ‚Äî classic V2 helper (still available, bound-actions only, multi-select aware).

Below is a stripped-down version of the demo controller Action.ts (V4) / ListReportExt.controller.js (V2). Notice how the pattern is always the same: pick the selected contexts, call invokeAction(), pass parameters if needed.

// 1) Bound action WITHOUT parameters
export async function customPromoteBook(this: ExtensionAPI) {
  const ctx = this.getSelectedContexts();
  await this.getEditFlow().invokeAction("BookshopService.promoteBook", {
    contexts: ctx
  });
}

// 2) Bound action WITH parameters
export async function customSetDiscount(this: ExtensionAPI) {
  const ctx = this.getSelectedContexts();
  await this.getEditFlow().invokeAction("BookshopService.setDiscount", {
    contexts: ctx,
    parameterValues: [
      { name: "percentage", value: 15 },
      { name: "reason",     value: "HOLIDAY_SALE" }
    ]
  });
}

// 3) Unbound action WITHOUT parameters
export async function customRefreshCatalog(this: ExtensionAPI) {
  await this.getEditFlow().invokeAction("refreshCatalog", {
    model: this.getModel()
  });
}

// 4) Unbound action WITH parameters
export async function customGenerateReport(this: ExtensionAPI) {
  await this.getEditFlow().invokeAction("generateReport", {
    model: this.getModel(),
    parameterValues: [
      { name: "reportType", value: "sales" },
      { name: "dateFrom",   value: "2024-01-01" },
      { name: "dateTo",     value: "2024-12-31" }
    ]
  });
}

Why bother?

  • Quickly add dialogs, parameter defaults, or pre/post-processing logic without touching the backend.

  • Framework handles draft save, busy state and message pop-ups for you.

  • One handler works for multi-select (just pass an array of contexts).

  • You can mix CAP-generated buttons and CUST buttons side-by-side to compare approaches.

Fiori elements API

Supports

Recommended for

getEditFlow().invokeAction()

Bound + Unbound actions, parameters, V4

Modern Draft-aware V4 apps

extensionAPI.invokeActions()

Bound actions, multi-select, V2

Classic V2 List Report/Object Page

That‚Äôs the entire toolbox for custom code inside Fiori elements ‚Äî no need to switch to freestyle unless you want total UI freedom. Jump into the repo, press the CUST * buttons and check the dev-tools network tab to see each API in action.

API decision matrix 

Scenario

Recommended API

Why

Fiori elements V4

CAP annotations or invokeAction()

Auto buttons, framework busy-handling

Fiori elements V2

CAP annotations + extensionAPI.invokeActions()

Multi-select, side-effects, Fiori elements only API, only for bound actions

Freestyle V4

bindContext().invoke()

Modern Promise API (requires UI5 1.123+)

Freestyle V4

bindContext().execute()

available since 1.37, deprecated in 1.123; keeps working for backward compatibility

Freestyle V2

ODataModel.callFunction()

Works everywhere, all action types

Rule of thumb ‚Äî start with annotations for business logic, move to custom controller code only where UI-specific behavior is needed.

That‚Äôs it! Clone the repo, start cds watch, and explore each app to see the different APIs in action. 

Also, create a Pull Request or Issue if a sample implementation is missing to complete the Guide!

entry.title: identify all services have been running in S/4 HANA
entry.content: We plan to relocate the S/4 HANA on-premise server to another location and need to change the IP address. Before doing this, we need to identify which external systems are communicating with SAP. Is there any tool that can help identify which services have been running in S/4 HANA over a period of time? This includes services where external systems are calling S/4 HANA, as well as services where S/4 HANA is calling external systems, regardless of whether they are RFC services, HTTP/HTTPS services, WebService services, or any other types of services. All of these should be included in the statistics. Finally, the data should be logged into a log file, which includes information such as service type, service port, interface direction (inbound or outbound), remote IP address, remote port number, and the number of calls. Could you recommend any tools to accomplish this? It is not limited to SAP TCODE; operating system-level tools or specialized software tools are also acceptable. Thank you!

entry.title: Re: Connection for VIES VAT Registration Number Validation
entry.content:
Hi All, 

in general, the status code 405 is OK for direct connection to VIES. 

The VIES service end point expects http POST requests, however, the connection test sends http GET requests. The code 405 means that the GET requests reached the VIES end point, but VIES refused to handle the GET requests. But it means that the URL is correct and there is no obstacle in the communication. 

During the validations, the system correctly sends POST requests. 

Best regards, 

Pavel

entry.title: Integration Advisor ‚Äì multi-payload support for MIG creation
entry.content:
Today I would like to share with you another new feature: When creating a Message Implementation Guideline (MIG) based on payload, you can now supply multiple payloads and all payloads are considered together by the application. In this blog post I will provide a short description of this new feature.  

The picture before depicts the overall building blocks of Integration Advisor (of SAP Integration Suite). This blog post mainly relates to the Message Implementation Guideline area.

Short recap: Payload-based creation of MIGs

Earlier this year I had shared with you a larger extension of our payload-based MIG Creation feature. With the extended feature you were able to provide a single payload and choose the MIG nodes that shall get automatically qualified. As a result, each qualifier value  present in the payload will create its own qualification variant in your MIG. Moreover, all nodes present in your payload will get automatically selected and example values are created based on the payload. For more details, please see my earlier blog post: Link 

By the way, this blog post also discussed in detail when you should qualify a MIG node in your MIG structure and when it is better not to qualify.

MIG Creation with multiple payloads

It quite frequently occurs that not all nodes or all qualification variants are present in only one payload. In order to use our payload-based MIG creation in the past, you needed to choose the best fitting payload for automatic consideration and afterwards add missing pieces manually. 

Now we have extended our payload-based MIG generation to also support multiple payloads. In the step Sample Payload  of the Create Message Implementation Guideline wizard you can provide a ZIP file containing multiple payloads. Refer next screenshot for an illustration.

Keep in mind the following technical details:

  • The ZIP file can have a maximum size of 10MB and up-to 25 payloads will be considered.
  • The options SAP Cloud Integration and SAP Process Integration expect XML files as input.
  • The third option EDI Flat File is only available for EDI Type Systems (like ASC X12 or UN/EDIFACT) and requires TXT files.
  • Your ZIP archive might contain other files types (like PDF,  XSD etc.) - these are simply ignored.
  • Your ZIP archive might come with subfolders and all suitable files are extracted from the complete archive.
  • Additionally, the extracted payload files (XML or TXT files depending on your choice) must fit to the Message Type for which you want to create your new MIG. Otherwise these payload files can't be considered.

The MIG Creation wizard now finishes with a pop-up window that summarizes which payloads were successfully applied and which payload files in the ZIP archive were not suitable. For an example refer the screenshot above.

Result of the MIG Creation

All the (successfully processed) payloads will contribute to the automatic customization of your new MIG. More specifically:

  • Qualified nodes: If you have chosen the automatic qualification for a node (in step Select Nodes of the MIG creation wizard), each qualifier value  present in at least one of the payloads will create its own qualification variant.
  • Selection of nodes: A node will automatically get selected in your MIG if the node is used in at least one of your payloads.  

Please note that the option to add Example Values is not available in case of multiple payloads because input from several payloads can't be combined to auto-generate the MIG Example Payload in a meaningful way.  

Conclusion

With this feature extension you can benefit from the payload-based MIG creation even more as it allows you to build your Message Implementation Guidelines (MIGs) faster and with less manual effort.  

Further reading

https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blogs-by-sap/integration-advisor-overview-of-components-for-... 

https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blogs-by-sap/integration-content-advisor-create-a-customized... 

https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/integration-advisor-payload-based-qualification-at-time-of-mig-creation/ba-p/13990599

entry.title: New Localized Country/Region Concept for SAP Cloud ALM
entry.content:
In SAP Cloud ALM, we‚Äôre continuously adding new features and functions to improve usability and daily efficiency for our end users. As we‚Äôre integrated and used in conjunction with many other SAP solutions, sometimes a change comes along that requires a bit more work and a lot more explanation. One such change involves on how localized country/region versions are used in SAP Cloud ALM. Here‚Äôs a quick overview of what‚Äôs changing, and how it will impact users of Process Management and Process Authoring.

 

Moving the Needle from Processes to Diagrams

For anyone unfamiliar with the background: the standard content that provides the basis for much of Process Management in SAP Cloud ALM comes from SAP Best Practices made available in the SAP Enterprise Architecture Reference Library (often referred to as EARL for short). Until now, whenever various localized country/region versions were needed, EARL maintained them at solution process level. This is why you‚Äôll have seen a long list of separate solution processes for Accounting and Financial Close (J58), for instance, as each one represents a local version for one or multiple countries/regions.

What‚Äôs changing very soon is that EARL is moving the point of localization from solution process to solution process flow diagrams. This means that each diagram will have the country labels of the countries they are designed for. To prepare for this, localized versions for solution process modeling in SAP Cloud for ALM are therefore now created and maintained at diagram level and no longer at solution process level.

 

One other small but notable change: to harmonize the user experience throughout SAP solutions, the term now used to describe items that are valid for all localized countries/regions is Global, which replaces the previous term Generic:

 

A Major Benefit for SAP Cloud ALM Users

So what are the advantages of this change? Well, not only does this reduce the number of solution processes coming from SAP Best Practice content, it also allows SAP Cloud ALM users to choose exactly the right country/region diagram versions they need for their current implementation work (such as fit-to-standard workshops). All localized diagram versions used within a solution process are then aggregated and displayed as a consolidated list for the solution process.

Going forward, you might think of this change as laying a foundation for a more flexible, multi-stage approach for your implementation tasks based on those countries you want to focus on at a certain point in time. Looking even further down the line, the future vision even hopes to improve the country dimension at scope level, essentially allowing users to target localized content depending on their current needs:

 

A Look at the Launchpad

A glance at the Process Authoring app quickly reveals what‚Äôs changed. You‚Äôll still see countries/regions listed for the solution processes of course, as the underlying diagram versions are aggregated up to solution process level. But if you call up a process and look at its Solution Process Flow, you‚Äôll start to see some differences. Hitting the dropdown next to the diagram name brings up a list of available solution process flow diagrams (as before), but now you‚Äôll see country codes indicating which versions are available. Hover over them to reveal the full country/region if needed, or click More to display a full list in alphabetical order.

There‚Äôs also a new filter icon to the left that lets you prefilter the list of country/region diagrams that are displayed, helping you select only those diagrams that are needed for your current work (like fit-to-standard workshops). You can check out the Help Portal for full details.

In general, the solution processes in Process Management delivered with the standard Best Practices content will cover more country variations. And if you need to copy a solution process, the corresponding localization information will be carried over into Process Authoring, where you can maintain the country/region details at solution process flow diagram level going forward.

Finally, when creating new test cases in the Test Preparation app, you‚Äôll notice that you can now see the countries/regions for which the available solution process flow diagrams are relevant. This helps you choose exactly the right country/region diagram version for which the test case should be created.

 

All in all, quite a big mindset change in terms of the process modeling localization concept used within SAP and SAP Cloud ALM in particular, but hopefully one that will simplify things for users going forward and provide them with greater flexibility at different points of their implementation projects.

entry.title: Re: STO creation with Quality/Blocked stock type
entry.content:
With some below workarounds, you can try

You can post the Q-stock manually to quality status with movement types like 322 or 344 without triggering an inspection lot. This will allow the system to treat it as "available for planning" but not blocked by QM processes
In SPRO for QM in MM, deactivate inspection lot creation for movement types like 301 or 303/305. This prevents automatic inspection lot creation during STO, allowing Q-stock to move freely.

entry.title: Amazon Seller Central SAP S4 HANA integration Part 2 - Fulfilled by Merchant
entry.content:
Banner Image - SAP S4 HANA and Amazon FBM Integration Explained.

Just incase you landed on this directly, this is a second chapter of how you can integrate SAP S4 with Amazon Seller Central if you are operating under Fulfilled by Merchant model. In the first part - How to get started with SAP S4 HANA and Amazon Seller Central integration,  I discussed how I started building SAP Integration with Amazon Seller Central. The challenges and difficulties in getting and maintaining Amazon developer ID. We also talked about various Amazon API structure and various Amazon merchant models.

Understanding Amazon FBM process using SAP S4 SAP Sales and Distribution (SD) cycle

In this post, we are going to be talking about how you can integrate Amazon in case of Fulfilled by Merchant (FBM) scenario. I assume that most of the audience here would be well versed in SAP Sales and Distribution. If you are too, FBM is a drop ship kind of arrangement with Amazon, where customers come and place an order on Amazon, the shipping happens from Merchant‚Äôs warehouse.

What is Amazon FBM Model

Amazon then settles account with Merchant on a periodic basis. If you are with me so far, you got the important gist of the process. Let me show you how you can integrate FBM process using standard SAP SD cycle.

Let us break the integration into individual components.

  • Merchandize and catalog sync
  • Inventory synchronization
  • Amazon Order syncing with SAP
  • Out going delivery and tracking number
  • Invoice generation and A/R Posting
  • Return and refunds
  • Financial reconciliation between SAP and Amazon

A. Syncing merchandise with Amazon Seller Central Account

You may be selling only a part of your offerings on Amazon. Making a neat store with a proper tree structure and products assigned to them is of course the first step in getting started.

This is often done manually. Product information is enriched with proper images, description, related items for cross sell, specifications and more. See below Apple's store on Amazon with categories neatly laid out. 

Apple's Amazon Store with Categories and Sub-Categories

A key link to SAP‚Äôs material master and Amazon‚Äôs listing is the ASIN number. There are several ways to maintain ASIN numbers within SAP.

  • Text with Material
  • Custom table
  • Customer Material Info records
  • Unused field in Material Master

Customer material info records is the the cleanest way to do so. This is so because to be able to run SD cycle, Amazon has to be created as a business partner within SAP.

Maintaining Material Information in Customer Material Info Records with ASIN Numbers

 

It must be noted that the listings must be accurate and any orders placed for an item you have discontinued and are not being able to fulfill is dealt ruthlessly by Amazon. This reflects into your ratings and also search rankings.

B. Inventory Synchronization

You have to let Amazon know how much of each ASIN you have in stock ( ATP quantity). This becomes so crucial that it can make or break your Amazon store.

Syncing ATP Quantities with Amazon is a must for FBM Merchants.

As I mention that any orders placed on Amazon, if unfulfilled by merchant brings you down several notches and gives your closest competitor to rank above you.

Remember that SAP is your system of records. All B2B, EDI, Direct to Consumer orders being fulfilled centrally from the application. Each B2B order can change ATP across SKUs considerably.

So in essence, there are only two ways to deal with this situation.

  • Highly efficient integration which updates the inventory quantities several times a day.
  • Creating a separate plant or storage location exclusively for Amazon orders.

Another dimension to inventory sync is multi location stock.

If your inventory is spread across multiple warehouses in different regions, it‚Äôs best to sync these stock levels to Amazon. Amazon uses its intelligence then to calculate the estimated delivery time when customer sees the product. Receiving the product in 6 days versus 2, could be the single deciding factor for him to place order to browse other merchants.

 

C. Syncing Amazon FBM orders into SAP S4

The single most important aspect of this sync for all merchants is getting Amazon FBM Orders into their ERP, as efficiently as possible. This helps them get a window to be able to pick pack and ship the goods from the respective warehouse and let Amazon know the shipping details. 

In my experience working with several Amazon customers, a successful and optimized Amazon order in SAP should have the following key elements.

  • Amazon Order Number - I use PO number field for the same.
  • Shipping address - This not only ensures accurate shipping but also correct tax calculation. Remember that Amazon collects the tax on your behalf and it should match SAP‚Äôs calculation.
  • Bill to - This will be always Amazon for you.
  • Amazon Fees and Charges - You should have each Amazon fees and charges at the line item as mapped conditions type. Remember that some condition type can be statistical. For example the tax Amazon collected. If you do this part correct, the net amount payable by Amazon will match what it shows on your Amazon merchant portal. This I would say is the litmus test for orders synced.

Amazon Fees and Charges must be mapped to Condition Types within orders for better concilliation

  • Product and Quantities - Each ASIN must be converted to respective material numbers.

Litmus Test for Amazon Order Synced with SAP is that Net Amount must match what it shows as Payable on Amazon Portal

D. Outgoing Delivery and Tracking details

Amazon orders being shipped out of warehouse are usually small parcels. When PGI is done for these orders, tracking number should be related back to Amazon. Amazon notifies the end customer about the shipping details.

Amazon expects high operational efficiency from the merchants, specially the ones under FBM model.

Shipping goods as early as possible is really important for FBM Merchants

Hence, orders must ideally be shipped the same day, or even better within few hours.

This again calls for efficient and bi-directional integration.

While merchants may ship the goods in a timely manner, they are responsible for a timely delivery too. Hence any carrier delay also affects them adversely.

While this may seem unfair, there is a solution which Amazon offers around this. Amazon Veeqo is Amazon‚Äôs new acquisition which helps FBM merchant reduce their shipping cost as well as de risk them from carrier delays. Hence if a FBM merchant use Veeqo, any carrier delay doesn‚Äôt affect their ratings.

Bill of Lading is a good placeholder for storing tracking number for Outgoing Deliveries

E. Invoice

Interestingly, vendor invoice is not something Amazon is interested in getting. However for completeness of the process, merchants need to post SD Invoice when then post accurate receivables.

F. Return and Refunds

Amazon‚Äôs customer service and return policies are exceptional. When a customer returns goods, merchants need to raise a RMA. When goods are received at their end, Amazon issues them a credit.

In this case, a return order must be created in SAP with an inbound delivery and Post Goods Return followed by credit memo. The amount must match the respective line item in the original order.

G. Payment reconciliation

Amazon usually has a 2 week settlement cycle. This is amount paid for 2 week of sales net of returns. Given the volume of transactions, it becomes difficult to do it manually. A payment reconciliation report like the one below ease this entire process.

Why your Amazon settlement looks different from A/R shown in SAP

Despite doing the above integration, you may still find some differences in the amount you expected versus what Amazon paid you. This is so because there are some non order related, account level charges that may have been applied.

Some of them include any promotional event that you may have run with Amazon. Amazon also keeps a margin, some sort of deposit for every merchant. This margin safeguards Amazon to fulfill its commitment to customers on case merchant goes out of business. The margin amount d fluctuates as business transaction grows and hence adjustment may be required.

A few manual Adjustments may be needed despite integration

The good thing is that this is not usual or monthly phenomenon. Also these can be adjusted with few manual postings.

Without integration this entire reconciliation becomes manual and tedious.

Frequently asked questions

Here are some frequently asked questions regarding FBM questions in general and its integration with SAP in particular.

1. What is FBM and how is it different from FBA?

FBM stands for Fulfilled by Merchant. In this model, you (the seller) are responsible for storing, packing, and shipping the products when a customer places an order on Amazon.
On the other hand, FBA (Fulfilled by Amazon) means Amazon takes care of storing and shipping your products from its own warehouses.

2. How does the integration process differ for FBM?

In FBM, since the seller handles fulfillment, the integration focuses on syncing orders, inventory, deliveries, tracking details, and payment reconciliation between Amazon and SAP. You‚Äôre also expected to respond quickly to new orders and keep inventory up to date to avoid penalties from Amazon.

3. Is the integration approach different between SAP S/4HANA and SAP ECC?

The core logic remains similar, but S/4HANA offers improved capabilities‚Äîlike better data structures and more streamlined APIs‚Äîwhich can make the integration smoother. However, both require proper mapping of orders, products (ASINs), and financial data.

4. Can I consolidate Amazon orders into a single SAP order?

It‚Äôs not recommended. Each Amazon order should be created as a separate sales order in SAP. This ensures better tracking, accurate taxation, shipping, and proper return/refund processing.

5. Why is financial reconciliation so important?

Even after syncing all the order details, Amazon might deduct fees or hold a margin at the account level. Without regular reconciliation between Amazon reports and SAP receivables, these mismatches can cause accounting issues and missed revenue.

6. What is Amazon Veeqo and how can it help FBM sellers?

Veeqo is a shipping and inventory tool by Amazon, especially useful for FBM sellers. It helps reduce shipping costs and protects your account ratings from delays caused by third-party carriers. If the delay is on the courier side and you‚Äôre using Veeqo, Amazon won‚Äôt penalize you.

7. What is multi-location inventory and why is it important?

If you store inventory across different warehouses, syncing stock levels with Amazon helps customers see more accurate delivery timelines. For example, a buyer may prefer a seller who can deliver in 2 days versus 6. This improves chances of making a sale.

8. How do I link my SAP materials to Amazon listings?

You need to match each product‚Äôs ASIN (Amazon Standard Identification Number) with its corresponding Material Number in SAP. The cleanest way to do this is by using Customer Material Info Records in SAP, especially if Amazon is set up as a customer in your system.

9. How often should inventory be synced with Amazon?

Ideally, multiple times a day. Amazon expects real-time inventory updates to avoid overselling. If that's hard to manage, you could also dedicate a separate plant or storage location for Amazon orders to simplify tracking and syncing.

10. Do I need to send invoices to Amazon?

No, Amazon doesn‚Äôt ask for your invoices. But you still need to create and post invoices in SAP so your books are accurate and receivables are tracked properly.

11. What happens if I can‚Äôt fulfill an Amazon order?

Amazon is strict about fulfillment. If you fail to ship an order, your ratings and rankings take a hit‚Äîwhich can reduce your visibility and sales. That‚Äôs why tight integration and up-to-date inventory are critical.

12. How are returns and refunds handled in SAP?

When a customer returns a product, Amazon issues a credit. On your end, you should create a return order in SAP, do the Post Goods Receipt, and generate a credit memo‚Äîall while matching the original order details to keep records clean.

entry.title: Re: Character Limit
entry.content:
Hi Punita,

By default, if meta-enforce-rte-limit and/or meta-enforce-plain-text-length-limit is not configured in XML, then users can enter over 4000 characters without limit.

But please be aware that reporting only pulls 4000 characters for the comment field on form.

Related KBA: 
2372468 - How to Check if the Performance Form has a 4000 Character Limit 
2076500 - Performance Form and 360 Multi-Rater Form Character Limit for Comment Fields and Custom Text Area Field 

BR,
Yilin
SAP Support

entry.title: Re: Automatically assign a source of supply when changing...
entry.content:
Yes SAP intentionally set this validation such that if you change the plant, it clears the source of supply because, it might not be applicable to the new plant.

The only option to mass change is via LSMW with BAPI_PR_CHANGE or BDC. Prepare a spreadsheet of PRs and target plants. You can also include source list logic or defaulting from info records so that SAP select valid sources cleanly

entry.title: Re: Intercompany billing proccess for services on Profess...
entry.content:
Hi @LeventePosza 

thank you for raising this question. If the intercompany with scope items 16T and 4AN is set up properly it is also triggering the posting of the supplier invoice (accounts payable) in the receiving company, in your example German company code. The system is also generating with the invoice in the sending company a PDF document which is the intercompany invoice. This document is at the same time the "supplier" invoice for the receiving side and available in the S/4 system.

In case those postings are not done automatically please check the set up guide (available in the process navigator for scope item 4AN), which also includes the set up of the monitoring role in which you can see the journal entry ID of the receiving company.

Best regards,

David

entry.title: Re: Possible link between SAP Transportation Management a...
entry.content: SAP TM supports a 'cost distribution which is also known as Freight Cost Distribution. It allows proportional allocation of freight costs across reference documents like sales orders, inbound deliveries. Next configure the settlement interface so that when an FSD triggers PO creation, the data from the cost distribution is read and mapped. Split the service PO line into multiple lines if needed and assign appropriate account assignment category like K for Cost Center, P for Project. Finally, use BADI_TM_ERP_PO which will allow custom logic during PO creation from TM settlement to modify account assignment, read distribution data for proper CO tracking

entry.title: Re: Character Limit
entry.content: Hi Punita, I mean there's nothing you need to do if you don't want to set a limit. Users can type over 4000 without setting anything in particular. But if meta-enforce-rte-limit and/or meta-enforce-plain-text-length-limit is configured in template XML, there will be a 4000 character limit. Removing meta-enforce-rte-limit and/or meta-enforce-plain-text-length-limit will also remove the 4000 character limit. If you want to set 8000 character limit, then you would need to use required field. But if you want to report on the comment, please be aware that only 4000 characters can be pulled which is the current system behavior.

entry.title: Re: MM02 - Marc Custom Field Wont get updated for Certain Materials in Production
entry.content:
Possible root causes are

the field would not have assigned to all views and screen sequences. Go to tcode OMS9 to verify that your field is linked properly in the screen data for existing plant-specific views in PRD
Some fields required specific field group assignment for change document updates. Ensure your custom field in OMSR is part of the correct field selection group and marked as "change-relevant"
Since new materials work in PRD, I presume, the related TR would not have imported to PRD properly.  You may have missed transporting the change to existing MARC records' screen layout metadata.

Go to se10 to confirm all required screen config and field group transports are moved from QAS to PRD. May be you can cross check tables like T130F and T133F.

Ensure the BAPI_MATERIAL_SAVEDATA is correctly populating the field in client and plant-level structures
